title: mps debate banning stone age
story: Exclusive: MPs to debate banning Stone Age snares after petition passes , thresholdThe call, spearheaded by Animal Aid, will be the subject of a Westminster debate after campaigners succeeded in getting enough signatures to trigger a hearing in ParliamentA ban on the traps will be debated in ParliamentByBen GlazeDeputy Political Editor:,  Apr |commentsPlans to ban “barbaric” snares which trap wild animals will be debated in Parliament after an online petition was signed more than , times. MPs will arrange a date for a Westminster showdown on outlawing “Stone Age” devices that can wound and kill cats and dogs. TV presenter and campaigner Chris Packham backed calls for snares to be made illegal. He told the Mirror: “These Stone Age contraptions really have no place in today’s Britain. Get a daily morning politics briefing straight to your inbox.for the free Mirror Politics newsletter “They are cruel and barbaric, trapping something like . million animals every year and, in the process, causing horrendous suffering to wildle and domestic animals too.  “There is no justiable reason for snares to still be used in our towns and countryside – it’s high time we end this practice.” Opponents say snares - designed to catch foxes and other predators - also harm badgers, rabbits, lambs and even domestic pets which stray into the countryside. A petition urging the Government to “prohibit the sale, use and manufacture of free-running snares” has attracted more than , signatures. The demand warns that “people setting free-running snares cannot ensure animal welfare as required” and that snares “cause unnecessary suffering to mammals, are indiscriminate and should be banned”. Downton Abbey actor and wildle activist Peter Egan said it was “bewildering to think that there are people who would oppose a ban on snares”.  He added: “They are such cruel and unpleasant contraptions. “For a country that claims to protect wildle, it is bizarre that they’re still in use at all – they cause the most tremendous and unnecessary suffering.” Green MP Caroline Lucas said: “It’s shameful that in  we’re still catching, injuring and killing animals in the most inhumane and indiscriminate way. “Parliament supported calls for a ban on snares as long as six years ago, and yet we’ve seen no concrete action.  “The Government must urgently bring an end to this horric practice by outlawing the sale, possession and use of snares immediately.” Paying tribute to the National Anti-Snaring Campaign and Hunt Investigation Team’s work on fighting for a ban, Animal Aid director Iain Green said: “We’re delighted that more than , people have signed our government petition to ban snares. “Clearly, the public want to see an end to these hideously-cruel, archaic, torture devices that trap, maim and kill millions of animals, and we will now take the campaign to ban snares to Parliament. “No animal deserves to be trapped by a wire noose and we are sure that, judging by the strength of public opinion on this matter, we will get a ban on snares.” Responding to the petition, the Government said it “recognises that some people consider snares to be an inhumane and unnecessary means of trapping wild animals and will launch a call for evidence on the use of snares”. title: nearly 15bn blown useless covid
story: Exclusive: Nearly £.bn blown on useless Covid PPE bought through governments VIP laneThe eye-watering sum spent during the pandemic on inadequate masks, gowns, goggles and gloves could have funded , new NHS nursesA colossal sum was spent on PPE that was inadequate [file pic] Image: Getty Images iStockphotoByAndrew Buckwell:,  Apr |commentsNearly £.billion of taxpayers cash was blown on useless Covid PPE bought through the Government’s so-called “VIP lane”.The total was officially revealed by the Department of Health and Social Security this week after pressure from two Labour MPs. And the money wasted on inadequate masks, gowns, goggles and gloves desperately needed by the struggling NHS would have paid for , new nurses. The junk, some of which is being burned, was bought through a government High Priority Lane for PPE buying set up by Boris Johnson at the start of the pandemic.It let Tory MPs and top civil servants recommend companies to supply PPE.  Michael Gove, shamed ex-Health Secretary Matt Hancock and former minister Esther McVey were the biggest names among  Tories who brought contracts in – but they are not accused of any wrongdoing. The true depth of the scandal emerged after Labour deputy leader Angela Rayner and Public Accounts Committee MP Dan Carden put a written question to DHSC minister Edward Argar.His Commons reply confirmed that £.bn of £.bn worth of PPE “which cannot be used” or “was not suitable for use in the health and social care sector” had been bought through the VIP lane. The lane was ruled unlawful by High Court judge Mrs Justice O’Farrell in January. Mr Carden said all suppliers of PPE ­products not fit for purpose should be made tothe money. He said. “Those responsible must be held to account and steps taken to recover losses.”  Ms Rayner added: “Unusable masks, gowns, goggles and gloves our frontline key workers desperately needed are now literally going up in flames, along with billions of taxpayers’ cash spent on it. “The next Labour government will establish an Office for Value for Money that would ensure taxpayers’ cash is treated with respect.” The DHSC claims around £m of PPE was not fit for use and a further £.bn was unsuitable for NHS staff. That means it could only be used in settings such as schools..  A spokesman said: “We have delivered over . billion items of PPE to frontline staff to keep them safe. “Of the PPE we procured, % is fit for use.” Read MoreRead More Most Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON Labour PartyNHSEsther McVeyMichael GoveBoris JohnsonCivil servantsPolitics" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get UK politics insight with our free daily email briefing straight to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. A new survey shows we are bottom of the European league when it comes to delivering the financial benefits of going plug-in. Danish motorists get the best deal with savings of more than £, within  months of choosing electric over petrol. The comparison site money calculated the average price of buying a new car plus the cost of , miles of travel in ten dferent countries in the first year. That showed Danes would spend £, on an EV plus travel costs compared to £, for a petrol driven car, a saving of more than %. A litre of unleaded in Denmark costs £.. A British motorist would shell out an average of £, on electric and £, on a traditional car, costing an extra .%.  Germans are £ worse off by going plug-in though the percentage dference is higher than the UK’s at .%. James Andrews of money said: “Denmark leads the way. story: Top Tory says stats somewhat misleading over fears , kids could be pushed into povertyIn the wake of Rishi Sunaks spring statement which did little to support the poorest Brits, leading think-tanks revealed that around .million people will be pushed into absolute poverty. Image: Getty ImagesByAletha AduPolitical Correspondent:,  Apr Updated:,  Apr |commentsA Tory minister today suggested poverty statistics released in the wake of Rishi Sunakaposs spring statement that did little to help struggling families, are somewhat misleading.Transport Secretary Grant Shapps said he didnapost want to get Brits lost in numbers but said poverty is ided into both absolute and relative. This does not rule out the fact that around .million Brits will be pushed into absolute poverty, including , children, as the Chancellor refused to raise benefits - which will rise at less than half inflation. story: Britains vainest man ditches cosmetic surgery after spending £, on faceSam Barton, , has had Botox, veneers, fillers in his cheeks, lips, jaw and chin amid speculation he wanted to look like reality TV star Joey Essex.Sam Barton says he has changed his waysByAndy Richardson:,  Apr |commentsBritainaposs self-proclaimed aposvainest manapos has given up unnecessary cosmetic surgery after shelling out £, to transform his face. Sam Barton, , has had Botox, veneers, fillers in his cheeks, lips, jaw and chin amid speculation he wanted to look like reality TV star Joey Essex.But he says he has now given up the treatments and his old party lestyle following the pandemic and is instead focusing on his business - which specialises in cosmetic work, reports Birmingham Live.Barton has also stepped away from social media and says some of his surgery was pointless in his quest for fame. I used to spend £, on a bottle of Champagne, he said. I was just interested in being pictured on a night out enjoying a lavish lestyle so I could post the pics on Instagram and other social media.I wanted fame and I said some stupid things in the past just to get in the papers. I had surgery on my face and other parts of my body, which cost me thousands of pounds . It was pointless and - although I may give myself a little bit of workI think I need it - I will never undergo needless surgery again. I have changed.When I was younger and partying every night, I wasnapost truly happy. I was constantly concerned about what I looked like. I was scrutinised on social media and it wasnapost having a good impact on my mental health. Donapost get me wrong. I still enjoy the occasional blow out - it is part of my personality. But the party lestyle doesnapost define who I am anymore. I was silly. I took advice on how I should behave with the media and told to say things which would get myself headlines. I wanted fame. I wanted to become a star but it was just so shallow.  I was never truly happy like I am now. I feel I am achieving great things through hard work. I often work six or seven days-a-week but it is paying off. I have just bought a house with the money I have made through my business. I am self-sufficient. Sam has used his experience of plastic surgery to set up his Sutton-based business, AMC Aesthetics. He said: It was due to open as we went into the first lockdown, which was a huge blow. Although I will not spend any more money on surgery transforming my body, I still have a keen interest in cosmetic work and I like to pass on my knowledge in the field to other people. story: Exclusive: Family squeezed in two-bed flat with no support after taking in Ukrainian relativesFamilies are being denied financial support as their relatives did not come to the UK under government sponsorship and are struggling to make ends meeting due to the cost of living crisisThe family are now all living under one roof and struggling to access support. The Refugee Council says many families are now struggling to make ends meet.In one case, a mum has taken in three Ukrainian relatives so that five people are now squeezed into her two-bedroom flat. Part-time merchandiser Elena Linyard went to Poland to bring her niece, sister and mother back to the UK after they fled Kyiv. But Elena, of Haringey, North London – who has lived here for  years – said: “My first instinct was to help my family. It would be nice to have a little bit of support. And there is no support for me.” Mum-of-two Elena, , and son Andrew, , are sharing a room, while her daughter Tanya, , has moved out to free up space for the guests. Her niece Anna Tkachnko, , and sister Iryna, , are sharing a double, while her mother Galyna Kryvulska, , is sleeping on a sofa bed. All those arriving from Ukraine are now able to claim benefits from day one. In addition, households welcoming refugees under the Homes for Ukraine scheme are offered a £ “thank you” per month while guests are given a one-off £ for “subsistence”.But Elena, whose bills will go up hundreds of pounds a month, won’t get anything. And her guests are not entitled to the £. Refugee Council chief Enver Solomon said: “Every Ukrainian refugee must be given a warm welcome with all the support they need.” The Government said the Homes for Ukraine and Ukraine Family schemes were among the “fastest and biggest visa programmes in UK history”, with over , visas issued and thousands more expected. So far,  councils have reported people presenting as homeless,  in the family scheme and  from Homes for Ukraine. Another  came via other routes. story: Gas vs electric: Which is cheaper to heat your home as cost of living crisis hits The UK Government has raised the price cap on energy bills from the start of this month, as experts predict thousands will be left choosing between heating and eatingBrits are examining ways to cut costs and heat their homes on a budget Image: Getty ImagesByHollie BoneNews Reporter:,  Apr |commentsMany Brits are looking for ways to cut costs as thousands across the UK will see a near-£ increase to their energy bills. In the midst of a cost of living crisis, with all-time-high inflation, national insurance tax hikes and rising interest rates, many have been fearful about the beginning of this new financial year. But the start of this month also saw the enormous rise in the price cap on energy bills set by regulator OFGEM, to a record £,. The soar in cost will mean the average household will see a rise of £ per year in their gas and electric bill.  So which of the two is cheaper to run  Most central heating models use gas radiators pumping hot warmer from a boiler to heat several rooms at once. Naturally, this can prove expensive as it uses gas over a wide area for several hours a day. The alternative is to heat only the room youaposre using or need to heat with an electric appliance that works independently. Electric heating units take their power from wall sockets rather than one central system, but this isnapost necessarily cheaper upfront.  While market chaos has made it near impossible to estimate accurate electricity and gas prices, tradespeople estimate the former is more expensive, The Express reports.Data reported by checkatrade from the last time prices were stable - in December  - show gas heating costs approximately .p per kWh.Electric heating is almost four times more expensive at p per kWh. But using electricity creates savings where, such as in installation. Gas central heating systems require the hand of a specially trained tradesperson and cost up to £, on average. Electric central heating systems cost markedly less, averaging out at £,.  Heaters not hardwired to the mains usually require a single plug socket, with no electrician necessary. But there are other factors to consider when considering whether to use electric heating. One such consideration is efficiency, as gas wonapost convert to heat at a : rate. Most research shows that, at peak efficiency, gas boilers are roughly  percent effective. Electric heaters generate one unit of heat per hour of operation. In the long run, electricity can give people more bang for their buck. title: great grandad 83 oxygen machine
story: Exclusive: UKs cruellest burglars steal £, funeral fund from great-grandad on oxygen machineGreat grandad John Jordan who has heart failure and lung disease had saved up £, to pay for his own funeral and callous thieves took money and even stole CCTV cameras from terried pensionerJohn Jordan was asleep in a chair at his home when burglars entered his property Image: Family handout - permission given for Reach plc useByBradley JollyNews Reporter:,  Apr Updated:,  Apr |commentsA frail pensioner robbed of the cash he was saving to help his family pay for his funeral said last night: “I don’t feel safe in my home any more.” John Jordan, , who has heart failure and lung disease, was hooked up to an oxygen machine and sleeping when ­the callous raiders broke in. The great-grandad woke up to find his window had been forced open and the £, he had painstakingly saved to spare his family the burden of his funeral costs was gone.The burglars had also taken the ­retired painter and decorator’s CCTV camera to cover their tracks. Heartbroken John told the Sunday People : “I just don’t want to be in this house any more. I don’t feel safe and this makes me angry. “I struggle to sleep at night worrying they will come back. I should not have to feel like that living in my own home. I will not be keeping money in the house any more. But I will never have that type of money again. “It took me a really long time to save and I felt at ease knowing I had that money there because it really would have helped my family when I am gone. “My family now have to help with everything.”  His granddaughter Chloe-Ann Preedy, , added: “He is very upset. This is an old, frail man and he’s been hugely affected by this. It has really hit him hard. “What they have done is absolutely disgusting. They are the lowest of the low. He is particularly upset as he hoped to save the money for his funeral and to help the family. “He is just old-fashioned like that. He is very selfless and is the most ­generous man.” John lives mostly in his living room ­because of his health conditions and his daughter, Jeanette Preedy, visits him up to five times a day in Milton Keynes, Bucks. After waking up and realising he had been robbed, the partially-sighted pensioner called the police, then Jeanette.  Chloe-Ann went on: “My mum hasn’t slept well since, being worried about him. All my mum and dad want to do is help my grandad. “Police think there was more than one person because the window – which grandad usually leaves slightly open to help with his breathing – was open completely and the back door was open. “When he went to sleep, everything was locked – so someone must have climbed in through the ­window and opened the back door for the other one or two. “They’ve then sneaked past my grandad, taken the money and left through the front door. On the way out, they snatched the CCTV camera and threw it on the ground outside. Police found it but the footage ­obviously isn’t there.” John, who is also hard of hearing, had been keeping the money in his wallet at home because he struggles to use the bank.  Chloe-Ann, who works as a carer, said: “He helps his neighbours a lot, so he likes to have cash at hand. “He gave a family nearby money when they were struggling to provide for their son. This is just how my granddad likes to be. He has the kindest soul and will go out of his way for everyone.” She added of John’s ordeal: “He is usually so strong but he is so upset now. “He actually doesn’t want to live there any more. He’s been there for at least  years and it’s been his haven – but he doesn’t feel safe now. “It is not a nice time at the moment. We as a ­family are not sleeping properly.” Thames Valley Police confirmed that officers ­had attended John’s address on March .They said the burglary was believed to have taken place some time between ­midnight and .am. A force spokesman ­added: “Investigations are ongoing.” John’s family have since started a crowdfunding appeal in a bid to ­replace his stolen cash.You can donate to the appeal here. Chloe-Ann said: “We are very ­grateful to those who have helped out so far. We’d love to be able to show grandad that people do care. “We appreciate all of your support and we would like to say a big thank-you to everyone who has shared our posts and donated.” Anyone with information should call  and ask for Thames Valley Police. story: Kids as young as  run riot as shops demand crackdown in ridiculous ongoing battleYoung people have been riding bikes into the Merseyway Shopping Centre in Stockport, Greater Manchester, with shopkeepers complaining of thefts and anti-social behaviourKids have been terrorizing Stockport town centre Image: Manchester Evening NewsByLyell Tweed:,  Apr |commentsGroups of young people have been riding bikes into stores and launching items around, shopkeepers have said. Stockport in Greater Manchester is currently enduring a surge of anti-social behaviour, with police issuing a warning to parents. Kids as young as nine have been up to no good in Merseyway Shopping Centre, haranguing workers and shoppers, Manchester Evening News reported. On one occasion a group of  boys and girls became embroiled in a large brawl before racing into shops and making a mess. According to shop workers things came to a head on March , when children rode their bikes around shops and launched items at each other.Have you been the victim of anti-social behaviour  Email webnews@mirrorThe incident prompted Stockport police to post a message on its Facebook page saying young people were aposrunning riotapos. Salim Patel has been working at Bhaji newsagents, just outside the entrance of Merseyway, for  years. He said that anti-social behaviour has always been an issue, but it has definitely increased in recent months. When we entered the shop and asked him about the police statement, he simply shook his head and said theyaposre causing so much trouble. They come in and ask for a vape but as soon as I ask for some ID they just start shouting abuse, Mr Patel added. A group of six will all come in at the same time with some just stealing stock, I tell them to stop what theyaposre doing but they just donapost listen. Iaposm in here on my own and need to be behind the kiosk, it can be very intimidating when thereaposs a big group.  I call for security straight away but by then itaposs already too late. You canapost say anything to themthey just donapost care. Sometimes itaposs absolutely terrible to work here. Iaposve been here  years but itaposs got so much worse recently, at the weekends there is so much trouble. I can see them stealing things but I just canapost do anything when thereaposs a big group. Sometimes kids are even coming in with their parents and stealing still, itaposs like theyaposre being encouraged too, but nobody listens. A senior sales assistant from HMV said that all the surrounding businesses were suffering, with groups running riot over recent weeks.Speak to any retailer here and theyaposll tell you the same thing, he said. You might get two or three groups all combining with crowds of at least  or so forming and looking for trouble. Last week we had someone, who could have only been nine or , ride their bike into the shop and make as much mess as they could. At the weekend there were lots of fights, all between themselves. Itaposs been a big problem recently. It can happen any day of the week too, not just weekends or school holidays when you might expect more kids around. At least two or three times a week thereaposs trouble kicking off with really young looking kids recently. Theyaposre just looking to get a rise out of someone. Itaposs like theyaposre wanting police or security to be called so they can have fun running away from it.  Itaposs been a bit better this week since the police did that post and hopefully more is done to keep on top of it. We canapost really do anything either, theyaposre just young kids. And they know that we can only really ask them to politely leave but nothing more. It seems like theyaposre doing this just because theyaposre bored, theyaposve got nothing better to do. The story was very much the same in the Ann Summers store opposite. Itaposs getting ridiculous now, one member of staff said. You can hear them coming and we have to go and stand at the store to stop them coming in. On Saturday a young kid rode in on his bike, itaposs crazy. People are always having to call security on their radio to help. If you argue with them they start throwing drinks around, itaposs become a massive problem now. Weaposve got a business to try and run but this going on just makes it a lot harder than it needs to be. You always see the same faces too. £Hopefully the police do genuinely deliver what theyaposre promising from that post, we need it.  There was a clear and large security presence around the shopping centre on a Thursday afternoon. One young man was stopped by security before trying to cycle through the Merseyway centre, with an argument starting when they were asked to leave their bike outside. One man shopping with his we, who wished not to be named, said: We used to come here every weekend for shopping or going to cafes. Itaposs okay around the market but can be terrible down here. Thereaposs always big groups around on bikes and these scooters. Police definitely need to be doing more about it. GMP Stockport have placed a lot of emphasis on parents to make sure their kids arenapost visiting the area after school and getting involved in trouble. The full statement from GMP Stockport said: Parents and s - Do you know where your kids are  Recently there has been a large increase in children aged nine to  coming to Stockport Town Centre and doing what I can only describe as running riot. I have charged my team to tackle this as it simply isnapost fair on people who are trying to go about their daily business, be that shopping, socialising, travelling, working or any other reasons. Please can I ask you all as parents, carers and s to speak to your children and make sure they are not coming to the town, after school and causing issues with their friends. We will be using our powers of arrest where they are required and conducting home visits to speak to youyou children are involved in less serious offences. Please help us, your community and your children by doing your bit to keep them out of trouble. title: lovestruck man fell esther who
story: Exclusive: Lovestruck man fell for Esther who he met online - before being fleeced of £,John Rousakis thought he had struck up a romance with a Canadian nurse called Esther Anderson - only for the  months of messages to be all lies as he was scammed out of £,Yannis Rousakis lost £, Image: Paul David DrabbleByEmer Scully:,  Apr |commentsLovelorn John Rousakis fell head over heels for a stunning brunette online... only to be fleeced for £,. He met so-called Canadian nurse “Esther Anderson” on a dating site and they enjoyed daily chats for  months. But the picture he was sent of “Esther” is a fake. And her cries for help and wild tales of being jailed for smuggling gold were total claptrap. Each time Esther asked for help, intelligent John transferred money from his account – even believing he would become the owner of two .kg gold bars worth £.million. John, , took out loans to give Esther £,., plus a further £, borrowed from his father. He was sent receipts for the gold. But it was entirely fictional.  John – who has an IQ of over  and a masters degree in engineering and robotics – fell for the crooks’ story after meeting Esther on dating website match. As the romance intensied over text messages and FaceTime, Esther told John she would move to Lincoln to be with him. She then asked him for £ a month for food and claimed she was desperate. John obliged and even went hungry himself to afford the gts. He tells the Sunday Mirror: “I always help people around me. I felt bad and I sent the money. “She said ‘Thank you my love and I can’t wait to come and meet you’ and things like that. “How would anyone feel when he hears affectionate words ” He was sucked in by pictures showing a smiling “Esther”.  The con took a twist when Esther said she was a volunteer and was heading to Africa to help build a children’s hospital. She would also visit her mother in Ghana before flying to see John in the UK. Just days later Esther claimed to have been jailed in Ghana for concealing the gold bars in a case. She asked John to pay a court fee to free her from jail. Then he received letters and documentation asking him to pay for the gold to be released. Esther saidhe paid officials she would give him the gold, or sell it and pay him back. But the amount demanded kept increasing. And John kept paying out to ensure the gold was released and he could get his money back. “I was expecting to get the money back when the gold was sold,” he says. “It turns out everything was a scam.” John took out four loans to release the gold and transfer it into his name. He says: “I only sent large sums of money to solicitors and police.  “I was dealing with supposedly official people. “They sent police badges and passports and everything. Esther never asked me for large amounts of money, just daily amounts for food.” He was sent a certicate from Straw P. Beachland Gold Mines Limited, which read: “This is to certy that John Rousakis, next of king [correct] Esther Anderson, is the holder of two bars of gold weighing .kg each.” A receipt in February  acknowledged £, had been paid. Another, in August that year, was for £,. With the sum borrowed by John’s father, the family ended up in £, debt. They saw nothing inand, in February , Esther disappeared. John says: “They kept it going for a year. We were talking daily. At one point I had handed over the money for the gold. They made a bank account for me. Everything was so well planned.” John came to the UK from Greece in  – three years after suffering catastrophic injuries in a car accident. He says the scam has wrecked his mental health, admitting: “I’m used to being used.” John has been awarded £, after Barclays admitted partial liability. The bank did not pay the full amount because it said the initial outgoing sums were small and did not raise concerns. It was only when a large amount was sent that Barclays admitted it had failed in its duty of care to warn John he could be victim of a scam. The money was sent to a non-UK account, making it impossible to access by Barclays. A bank spokesperson said: “This is a tragic case of a romance scam and we have every sympathy for our customer.  “The complaint has been thoroughly investigated, following which our customer chose to refer the case to the Financial Ombudsman Service and we await the conclusion of their review. “A scammer will use a iety of scenarios to target your emotions and get you to part with your money, often using a family emergency or an overseas crisis as a reason. “We encourage customers to always be vigilant and ensure they’ve taken the right steps to determine the person they are speaking to is who they say they are.” Chloe Roche, fraud team leader at CEL Solicitors, which handled John’s case, said: “The first international payment was unusual for the account. “ Barclays admitted they should have intervened. Don’t be ashamed. It happens to a lot of people. These scammers are sophisticated. They take advantage of people’s vulnerabilities and of their kindness.” Diana Fawcett, chief executive of the independent charity Victim Support, said: “Victims of romance fraud often blame themselves, but it is important to understand that this is an incredibly sophisticated crime, and that almost anyone can be targeted. “Victims may feel they have not only lost money, but also a loving partner or relationship they thought they had.” Read MoreRead More Most Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON BarclaysBanksHospitalsLoveMental healthCrimeCar crashesRomance" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. story: Man goes behind scenes at KFC to learn impressive secrets as th UK branch opensSam Honey from Kent Live was invited behind the scenes at the UKs th KFC branch in Sandwich, Kent to learn some of the impressive secrets behind the colonels delicious chickenSam Honey was invited behind the scenes at the UKs th KFC branch Image: KentLiveByHollie BoneNews ReporterSam Honey:,  Apr Updated:,  Apr |comments A man has gone behind the scenes at KFC to uncover their impressive secrets as the fast food restaurant opened their th UK branch.Sam Honey was given a backstage tour before he was taught how to make his own lunch at the new branch in Sandwich, Kent.But the journalist for Kent Live claimed he was incredibly impressed and taken aback by how much work goes into the aposfast foodapos as he documented every detail.Delving deep into the experience, Sam was even kitted out with a unorm as he joined his aposcolleaguesapos for the day in the kitchen.  He said: The day started with a thorough tour of the site, taking a look behind the till and into the kitchen at all of the state of the art fryers, ious storage chillers and freezers, plus numerous hand washing and cleaning stations throughout. Cleanliness really stood out as one of the most important practises in the kitchen, across the day I lost track of how many times I washed my hands which is obviously so important when handling food of any kind but especially chicken. The site was incredibly impressive, the whole kitchen was modern and thoroughly clean - the true sign of a well run kitchen.  The sheer amount of appliances in use really did take me by surprise also, countless fryers, cookers, defrosters and ovens, the list goes on. I suppose as you order fast food you tend not to think of all the inidual parts necessary to craft the end result. Not only this but the sheer speed and precision of the experienced staff when using all of this equipment was very impressive. As Sam rolled up his sleeves and got his hands dirty, he described breading the chicken as an artform. He said: The first step was to get the chicken breaded, an entire artform unto itself.Once Iaposd been given a very useful demonstration it was my turn, and I have to say I was very excited. The flower was so unbelievably soft, it felt like it was working absolute wonders for my skin and great fun to work with. To make sure each fillet is up to standard you must totally cover each, then fold over a hefty amount of the flower on top in one fluid motion before repeating the process for a total of  times. They are then dipped in water and breaded once more, again repeating the previous steps  times. After getting a real hands on experience with the breading process it was time to get cooking with the help of the shiny, new fryers.With all of the fillets ready on the grills, it was frying time which was every bit as satisfying as youaposd expect it to be. Dunking them into the oil was an easy process once I got my head around the mechanics of the fryer, though it did take me a couple tries mind you. After a few short minutes they were done, with a perfect golden coating and a smell that made me instantly hungry, I was now very eager to try the fruits of my labour. All that was left to do was get my fillet burger bunned-up, a portion of chips ready on the side and a drink to wash it all down. Before I knew it, my lunch was on a tray and ready to eat, tasting all the more satisfying after both seeing and helping with the creation process.  As his day came to a close, Sam claimed he left the branch with even more respect for KFC workers than before he arrived. He said: I left my visit with much more respect for all the hard work that goes on behind the scenes at KFC and all fast food chains. Itaposs easy to assume that fast food is easy to make given the name but I can assure you that your lunch time treat really does take a lot of effort from a skilled team. Definitely some food for thought to take away when your next in thought for food. story: Man who bought house in Italy for just p forced to give it up three years laterDanny McCubbin, , purchase the rundown house in Mussomeli, Sicily, for p but has been forced to give it up three years later because he couldnt find workers to renovate within that timeDanny bought house in Italy for p but had to renovate it within three year Image: Danny McCubbinByKirsty CardReporterLiam Buckler:,  Apr |commentsA man who purchased a rundown property in Italy for just p has been forced to sell his house - as he couldnapost find workers to renovate the property in time to meet a strict deadline. Danny McCubbin, , bought the house in Mussomeli, Sicily, where a aposCase  Euroapos campaign was launched to encourage foreigners to the area. The Aussie, who had been living in the UK for  years, decided the opportunity to own an overseas home at a cut down price was too good to turn down and urged others to do the same. However, the condition was that buyers had to renovate the house within three years of purchase to have complete ownership. And with labour shortages in Italy’s construction industry made the request tricky to fulfil as the chef – who has worked for Jamie Oliver’s Fteen Foundation – couldn’t find anyone to help him renovate his dream home within the time frame. He was forced to sell the property back to an estate agency after just a few months, receiving his payment back, as it was extremely dficult to find builders.Speaking to iNews, he said: “It was very dficult to find a builder and over time the house deteriorated.“By the time I did find a building company, it was double the cost to renovate it. I decided it was not worth it for me anymore.” Danny said he was disappointed, having enjoyed the quiet le in Mussomeli, a town of just , people.  However, it did not deter him as he managed to turn his hand to buying another cheap house for £,which required less work. In addition, he was able to find two construction workers to do a week of work for him, with the smaller fixes setting him back £, . This has now allowed him to settle into the home and he has now opened a community kitchen to make and deliver free meals to vulnerable families.He added: I moved here at the end of December , because I wanted to live in Italy when Brexit happened.“I’ve always wanted to live in Sicily, my parents loved the countryside. So I asked myself what was missing in Mussomeli and I came up with the idea of The Good Kitchen.”  And the labour shortage has promoted Mussomeli’s deputy to try and reduce the pressure on homeowners who are in desperate need of builders to help renovate their houses. And mayor Toti Nigrelli has since promised to alleviate the labour shortage for others hoping to purchase a cheap house at a reduced rate. title: mum spun web lies hide
story: Mum spun web of lies to hide £k theft from company she served for nearly  yearsAngela Boote, , lied repeatedly as she attempted to cover up her fraudulent activities and avoid being brought to justice after stealing over £, from a Liverpool insurance brokersAngela Boote, who worked for the insurance brokers for nearly  years, was described as a trusted and well-liked employee Image: Liverpool EchoByNick TyrrellSam Elliott-GibbsReporter:,  Apr |comments A crafty mum swindled a quarter of a million pounds from her long-term employers to fund a lavish lestyle of expensive holidays, clothes and jewellery. Angela Boote, , aposlied repeatedlyapos as she desperately tried to cover up her crimes and avoid being brought to justice. But the net closed on the brazen criminal, who was described as a trusted and well-liked employee and had worked for her company since , the Liverpool Echo reports.She has been jailed for three years and four months after stealing a total of £, through her role at Liverpool insurance brokers Grfiths and Armour. Over the course of a number of years the mum redirected cash intended for clients to bank accounts linked to herself and her family members.  Liverpool Crown Court heard earlier this week how Boote spent the cash to fund a “lavish lestyle” of expensive holidays, clothes and jewellery. Photos on her social media accounts, which are no longer public, show herself, her husband and their daughters in far flung destinations like Aruba in the Caribbean during the three year period she was stealing money.Sarah Grfin, prosecuting, also detailed to the court how Boote took extensive steps to cover her tracks - and continued to try to con her colleagues when they started to uncover her deceit. Suspicions were first raised in September  when Boote was away on holiday. A client complained to the company that a £ refund that they were due to receive had not entered their account.  Boote’s manager began to investigate the complaint, finding the bank details on the payment did not match those provided by the client. She contacted HSBC, the bank through which the transfer was conducted, to find out who the account belonged to and copied Boote into the email. At this point, Boote ed from leave and contacted HSBC numerous times herself, saying the issue had been resolved. At every turn, she tried to cut her manager out of the exchange, not copying her in to the emails. At one point, she even replied to HSBC and tried to make it look like her manager was copied in - but with her email address spelled incorrectly. Boote’s manager continued to question what had happened to the money and Boote finally admitted that she had sent into her daughter’s account. Yet even then Boote continued to lie, using the explanation that she must have incorrectly entered her daughter’s details because they were written down on a piece of paper next to her and she had planned to send her money from her personal account. At this stage, Boote’s manager reported the issue as a major error and an investigation of Boote’s accounts began. Eventually,  fraudulent payments were discovered and Boote was sacked shortly after. Recorder David Knton QC said Boote’s criminality was characterised from the start by complex attempts to cover up her dishonesty, with  paper trails created to hide her tracks. The court heard Boote had paid back around £, from inheritance received from an aunt and was being pursued for more cash through civil courts. Lionel Greig, defending, said Boote knew she had let herself and her family down and deeply regretted her actions. She will serve  months of her sentence in prison before being eligible for release under licence. Maryrose McCready, , from County Derry in Northern Ireland, initially believed she was suffering with the common ailment, which presents as bloating and constipation.Thinking she was reacting badly to food, she made drastic changes to her diet, which helped for a while - but her symptoms reared up again and persisted until they led to a rectal prolapse. She was later rushed to Altnagelvin Hospital in an ambulance after experiencing excruciating pain.Doctors referred her on for a colonoscopy, which revealed a tumour in her bowel, MyDerry reports. Maryrose told MyDerry: I just had a feeling whenever the rectal prolapse happened that there was just something that wasnapost right. I had the prolapse in May  and was then referred for a colonoscopy in the August of the same year. And in between that time my symptoms were getting worse, I had rectal bleeding, constipation, bloating and noises coming from my tummy. It was a massive shock for me when they told me that I had cancer. I was only -year-old and bowel cancer isnapost usually something somebody gets when theyaposre so young. Itaposs usually older people that are diagnosed with it.  This was something that was never discussed or never mentioned when I had gone to get checked by the local doctors and I had just thought that this was normal. Of course, I knew something wasnapost right whenever I had rectal prolapse but I still would never have guessed that it was cancer. She underwent surgery to remove a tumour from her bowel, meaning surgeons had to reattach her bowel after the procedure. Maryrose said she was completely floored by the entire situation which was a total blur at the time. I just wanted to get better, she said.I couldnapost even begin to comprehend how any of this was actually happening. Looking back now I definitely suppressed a lot of the mental side of being ill to the backburner. I just didnapost know how to react to the situation. I considered myself quite lucky because I didnapost have to get a stoma bag at the time or I didnapost have to have chemotherapy. This was the sort of way that I was thinking even know the situation was a godsend for me. I was mentally all over the place. I just wanted to get back to my normal le as quickly as possible. I was delighted when I had my two wee boys, Maryrose said. It was such a positive time in my le and I was really looking forward to seeing what the future held for us all. But there was some concern because at the start of my second pregnancy I started to get issues again with the bowel.Bloating, irritation and discomfort of the stomach all ed for the mum-of-two, prompting concern that Maryroseaposs problems were ing. She added: This went on until  when the pain became unbearable one night and I had to the AE department. There was nothing passing, no stool or air. They had to perform emergency surgery due to a blockage in my bowel. And even after that surgery I still didnapost feel right at all. My body was trying to tell me something. My bowel was enlarged in areas and felt completely twisted. Thataposs when I went back in March , just before the first lockdown, and thataposs when I had the CT scan.  Doctors investigating Maryroseaposs second blockage in less than a year, discovered two growths within the bowel - something which was described to her as a aposle and death situationapos. She said: I was told before the surgery started that I would need a stoma bag this time around but it would most likely be temporary. My large colon was also removed because it was so badly damaged that it couldnapost be saved. This left me with only my rectum and Iaposll need another operation in the future. Post ileostomy surgery, Maryrose admitted that she was in a dark place and hated having the stoma bag in. I was really conflicted at the time, she said. I really didnapost want this bag on my body but I knew that it saved my le. Thataposs what they told me. They told me thatthey didnapost perform the surgery there and then that I would I die and when youaposre left with a decision like that youaposre going to do whatever it takes to save your le. That when a local wax melt company, Brona at Urban Ivy Aromas asked methey could name their torso candle which was created with a stoma bag after me. in a block of council flats being covered in a disgusting, smelly black substance.Residents of the block of flats in Bristol said a great big bang was heard at about am on Fridayand then found an contractors at the time. The resident said that he reported what had happened to them and that, while two contractors came to take pictures, nothing had happened six hours later. Yesterday afternoon , the residents said the stench was filling the block of flats and that they were unable to go into their kitchens as they described them as a health hazard, reports BristolLive.Resident Martin Hewer said he had also turned his electricity off as a precaution because water is pouring through the ceiling of his tenth floor flat.Iaposm absolutely fuming, Iaposm furious - itaposs a scandal, he said. I talked to my neighbour who was out, and told him to come back, and his kitchen was the same. I donapost know how many flats are affected like this, but Iaposm on the tenth floor so it could be a lot of them.The council had contractors in doing something with the drains, and God knows whataposs gone wrong. I went and found them and told them, and two of them came up, had a look, took some pictures and then went off again. I havenapost seen them since. Mr Hewer, who is retired, also said heaposs waiting to hear back from the council, adding that he is worried for his health.I couldnapost believe what I saw when I walked into the kitchen. There was all this dirt everywhere, itaposs like a sticky black tar-like substance and it stinks. Obviously the kitchen is unuseable and Iaposm worried about what this substance is anditaposs safe to clear up - it needs professional cleaners because now my kitchen is contaminated with this black stuff.  It needs proper disinfecting - this is a health and safety issue, he added. Bristol City Council was contacted for comment. Bristol Live met another resident who said her flat had not been affected, although she said her sink hole was blocked with a plug. sensation after contracting Omicron.As a result, the app has added the symptom to its weekly ranking of the most commonly reported Covid symptoms, the Daily Star reports.Ear pain has been seen in the infection has passed. Lesley Larkin, Surveillance Lead, Gastrointestinal Infections and Food Safety, UK Health Security Agency said: As pandemic restrictions were lted and now people have begun to mix more, norovirus outbreaks have started to increase.  Symptoms include sudden onset of nausea, projectile vomiting and diarrhoea but can also include a high temperature, abdominal pain and aching limbs. Stay at homeyou are experiencing norovirus symptoms and do notto work or send children to school or nursery until  hours after symptoms have cleared. If you catch this bug, it is important to drink water to avoid dehydration and do not to visit elderly relatives, especially in care homes or hospital while unwell.Hand washing is key to help stop the spread of this bug, but unlike for Covid- alcohol hand sanitisers do not kill off norovirus, so soap and warm water is best.” Often norovirus outbreaks affect care homes and schools the most, with inhabitants of both spreading the virus to their families, once within the home it can spread into the wider community.The six main symptoms Vomiting Watery diarrhoea Feeling sick Aching arms and legs A high temperature A headache How to reduce the spread of norovirus:Stay at homeyou are experiencing norovirus symptoms, the UK Health Security Agency say. news uk-news prince-andrew-to-accompany-queen-"Queen arrives at Prince Philips memorial with Prince AndrewByRussell MyersRoyal EditorMilo BoydNews Reporter:,  Apr Scandal mired Prince Andrew will accompany the Queen to the Derby on the weekend of her Platinum Jubilee, it has been reported. The Duke of York, who settled a sex abuse case with Virginia Giuffre earlier this year, was named in a separate court case this week.Andrew has been featured in evidence given to a judge overseeing a High Court financial dispute between an elderly Turkish woman and a former banker.It has now been reported that the -year-old is in line to chaperone to Queen to Epsom races in June. A source told the Sun: “He was meant to stay invisible during the Platinum Jubilee so there is no way he will be at events like Trooping the Colour.  “But the Queen needs a chaperone on all occasions at the moment due to her mobility issues and Andrew has earmarked the Derby as the one he will accompany her at. “He just doesn’t seem to understand the public outcry.” Prince Andrewaposs role in the royal family has come into question following the end of the civil suit brought by Ms Giuffre earlier this year. He made no admission of guilt but settle the case for an undisclosed sum, understood to be £m. The settlement came in the months after he ed his military titles and royal patronages to the Queen. Amid such acrimony Andrew accompanied his mother to a memorial service for Prince Philip at Westminster Abbey this week. Prince Charles and nephew Prince William are said to have made their displeasure about the role Andrew played clear to the Queen.They did not want Andrew to be the one to accompany Her Majesty into the service on Tuesday, and reportedly spoke to her more than once to raise their concerns. The Queen went ahead and her so-called favourite son was the one seen across the world helping her along the aisle at Westminster Abbey, as the service was broadcast live on the BBC.The two heirs to the throne were said to have been “shocked” and dismayed” as Andrew emerged front and centre.  A source close to the Palace told the Mirror: [Andrew] was straight out the blocks in front of the cameras when the Duke of Edinburgh died, which was seen within the family as being completely inappropriate. “Now this situation has unfolded, a fair few hold the view that he is manipulating his position for his own gains. Vanity Fairaposs Royal Editor Katie Nicholl said the Queen deliberately chose to have Andrew play such a prominent role on the day and shows the public she still aposmakes the decisionsapos. Katie Nicholl said: This was the Queenaposs way of showing two things one, that the buck stops with her, and she makes the decisions, and secondly that she believes heaposs innocent. She made the point very, very clearly.  But Charles and William were very aware of the perspective, of the optics of this. Unfortunately, this picture [of Prince Andrew escorting the Queen] has overtaken what should have been a memorial to a great man. Andrew has spent a considerable amount of time with the ailing -year-old monarch, who has suffered from a series of health problems in recent months as well as recovering from Covid.The Duke of York, who lives on the Windsor estate, has also been ever present at his mother’s Windsor Castle home after the death of her beloved husband Prince Philip, who died last April aged . story: Queen made colossal mistake by letting Prince Andrew to escort her to Philip memorialChoosing to be escorted to and from Westminster Abbey by a man who paid a reported £-million to settle a sordid sex case to avoid court was deeply distastefulPrince Andrew and the Queen arrive at the memorial service Image: PAopinionByKevin MaguireAssociate editor:,  Mar What a cynical, gratuitously offensive attempt by the Queen to rehabilitate shamed son Andrew. Buckingham Palace will calculate an elderly monarchaposs above criticism on the day of her dear, dead husbandaposs memorial service. But choosing to be escorted to and from Westminster Abbey by a man who paid a reported £-million to settle a sordid sex case to avoid court was deeply distasteful. It wasnapost a sweet old maaposam who wanted to travel from Windsor Castle in state limousine with a scoundrel shunned since paying off a woman who alleged when a teenager she was force to sleep with a dad of two old enough to be her own father.  This was an elderly monarch exploiting sympathy at a personal yet very public event to walk back into polite society a reviled man forced to give up even honorary membership of a posh golf club over the scandals spewing from a close friendship with a convicted paedophile and his jailed fixer. What Virginia Giuffre makes of it one can only imagine but much of the watching world, particularly women victims of abuse, will have been revolted. The removal of his military titles and royal patronages, including the use of a His Royal Highness title, look a ersion.  The Duke of York, her favourite son, remains promoted despite stomach-churning behaviour that shouldaposve seen tainted Andrew seated out of sight at the back behind a pillar. Perhaps age and frailty are distorting her judgement because this was a colossal mistake by a declining monarch. She put her son and family before decency, trying to sell a leper to the country at a service commemorating her husband. Knee-bending courtiers will struggle from now on to argue sheaposs principled and does what is right in the service of the country.  She held on to Andrewaposs arm but it was her parading him. He continues to deny the claim but embracing the humiliated sex case settler damaged her own reputation. After the disastrous royal colonial relic tour of the Caribbean, the head of the creaking institution also undermined a family business suddenly feeling very out of date. story: UK weather: Brits face more freezing weather later in April raising Easter snow chancesAfter the sunniest March in a decade the country is now braced for an icy blast of winter weather which could mean a white EasterA frosty start to the day Image: Alex Lentati LNPByStephen Hayward:,  Apr |commentsBritain is springing back to winter after the sunniest March in nearly a century. The start of April feels more like January and wintry conditions, swept in by icy north Atlantic air, are set to continue this week.Long-range forecasters predict more freezing weather will strike mid-month, raising the chance of the UK’s first white Easter in five years.Today, bookmakers slashed the odds on this being the coldest April on record. But while many of us have shivered indoors, working outwe can afford to put on the heating again, others have made the most the ­bracing conditions outside.  Skiers and snowboarders hit the slopes at Lecht Ski Centre in the Scottish Highlands as hardy jet skiers and sea swimmers braved the waves in the North East. And dog walkers wrapped up warm to take their pets for a stroll in Richmond Park, West London. Coral spokesman John Hill said: “The prospect of snowfall during the Easter weekend is now strong.” Last month, temperatures hit C in some areas. It was the the ­sunniest March in the UK since .  Since then, temperatures have fallen. Tomorrow should be nearer the April average but a second Arctic blast, and possible snow, is expected later this week. Met Office forecaster Sarah Kent said: “It’s not that unusual to see snow around Easter time. a sunny Sunday with temperatures expected to hit C across parts of the country after a freezing night. Frost crept in overnight with temperatures plummeting as low as -C in some areas. Forecasters said the peaks and troughs of spring will hit most of the country over the next week, with sunny spells and windy intervals expected in most regions.Sunshine and dry weather could warm up most parts of the UK on Sunday, but rain is likely to edge in over Northern Ireland and Scotland.Met Office meteorologist Simon Partridge said: A wetter and windier day round there and we could see some strong, possibly gale-force winds around Scotland. The sunny weather will be brief, with bands of rain and wind forecast for the week ahead and into the Easter weekend. Looking to Thursday April  - Saturday April , the Met Office said: To end the week and through the weekend, it is likely to be cold in the north with wintry showers. Further south, weather systems coming in from the southwest will bring more prolonged spells of rain and strong winds.  There is a risk of snow at times on the northern edge of the bands of rain, this mainly across central and northern areas. Widespread frosts are expected in the north, with some icy patches likely. story: Woman accused of one of the worst ever fly-tippings as  tonnes dumped at clubMiddlesbrough Council safety wardens said they had uncovered one of the worst fly-tipping incidents they had seen in the town with  tonnes of waste dumped at a social clubMelanie Gibson, , who appeared at Teesside Magistrates Court Image: TeessideliveBySue KirbyLiam Buckler:,  Apr Updated:,  Apr A woman has appeared in court in connection with aposone of the worst everapos fly-tipping incidents in Middlesbrough. Melanie Gibson, , of Middlesbroughaposs Cresswell Road, pleaded not guilty to a charge of dumping waste without a permit in the town.Last year, TeesideLive reported Middlesbrough Council safety wardens said they had uncovered one of the worst fly-tipping incidents they had seen in the town with  tonnes of rubbish dumped at the old Turford Social Club in Brambles Farm.The waste discovered included large amounts of household waste, building materials and household appliances which were ditched at the site, while unused buildings were filled with rubbish and set on fire. The uncovered rubbish was discovered by Middlesbrough Councilaposs Environmental Neighbourhood Safety Wardens.  Melanie Gibson denied knowing anything about the fly-tipping when she appeared at Teesside Magistratesapos Court. She said: I didnapost know it was there until I saw it in the Gazette and on the news. Catherine Cunningham, representing Middlesbrough Council, told the court that in total  tonnes of waste had been dumped at the site. A specialist waste removal company had to be brought in to clear the mess.  Gibson faces one charge of depositing controlled waste without a permit between April ,  and May, , . The case was adjourned for a trial to be held at the court on May  at am. In addition, Darren Mills, , of the townaposs Shakespeare Avenue, also faces three charges in connection with the same fly-tipping incident, however, he failed to turn up at court for the hearing.  Meanwhile, he is charged with depositing waste without a permit between April ,  and December, , . And during the same dates he is also charged with treating controlled waste in a manner likely to cause pollution and operating a regulated facility without a permit. His case was adjourned until Thursday, April  at am. And as I was laying on the brick, I closed my eyes and prayed and asked the Lord for forgiveness for whatever I did in this le. Because I definitely knew Iaposm gonna go to another one and I didnapost want to go. Traumatised Cheslin awoke from the brutal attack partially deaf and not knowing whether Hannah was dead or alive.  In fact Hannah had been driven to a farm road, where the gang claimed they had planned to leave her alive until she began to struggle and was stabbed in the neck. During the trial, Parsons said they believed they had killed Cheslin and admitted being the first one to rape Hannah.According to Times Live, he told the trial: She didn’t want to climb out of the boot. She was holding on to the car. She started panicking.“Eben came up and stabbed her.  But family friends of Hannahaposs claimed she would have tried to comply with her killersapos requests and even empathise with them in a bid to survive. After killing Hannah, the men continued their terrying crime spree, chasing a woman walking to work in nearby Kraaontein before stealing her bag and phone. The group were then arrested following a high-speed police chase after Hannahaposs car was spotted by undercover cops. Her cruel killers were sentenced to a combined  years behind bars with three out of four facing le sentences following the trial at Cape Town high court.  Her heartbroken father Willem admitted during the trial that it had taken him a while to attend the court hearing because he didnapost want to hear what had happened to his beloved daughter - who was described as a aposdaddyaposs girlapos. Willem and Anna went on to create the Hannah Cornelius Foundation to help children in their local area get into education and escape violence within their community. Friend Toni, who went on to become director for the foundation told the Sun Online: Hannah was never a typical child, teenager or adult. She was always unusually compassionate and empathic and deeply moved by the people she encountered, their stories and their struggles. The way in which she saw the world and wrestled with her place and purpose therein was paradoxically both mature and innocent.  Hannah could be naively carefree and even careless at times. A dreamer. An idealist. Distracted and curious. But not many people saw her struggles and her personal suffering, which she carried bravely and faced fearlessly. Hannah loved completely. Firstly her parents and brother, but also friends and often even strangers. She suspended judgement and sought to know and understand. Itaposs easy to idealise the dead. story: Russias retreating forces laying mines and booby-trapping corpses, claims ZelenskyThe Ukraine President says Russian forces are laying mines and tripwires in homes, equipment and even among the war dead to leave a trail of destruction as they retreat northRussian forces have retreated but are feared to have left mines behind Image: REUTERSByDan WarburtonNews ReporterSean Rayment:,  Apr |commentsVladimir Putin’s retreating troops have begun booby-trapping corpses, Ukraine’s President Zelensky has claimed.It comes as Russia yesterday vowed to target Brit weapons as they are shipped to Ukraine.Soldiers leaving the Kyiv outskirts have been laying mines and tripwires in homes, equipment and even among the war dead, claimed Ukraine’s president.The news came as Kremlin ambassador Andrey Kelin warned our defence secretary Ben Wallace risked making the war even “bloodier”.It follows reports a Russian helicopter was shot down by a high-velocity portable anti-air missile supplied by the UK, called Starstreak. A video posted online showed the tail of a Mi-N helicopter being snapped off over the Luhansk region in eastern Ukraine  Wallace had previously vowed to send more “lethal aid” to Ukraine after Russia invaded in February. Kelin told Kremlin News agency TASS: “All arms supplies are destabilizing, particularly those mentioned by [UK Defense Secretary Ben] Wallace. “They exacerbate the situation, making it even bloodier. Apparently, those are new, high-precision weapons. “Naturally, our armed forces will view them as a legitimate targetthose supplies get through the Ukrainian border.” President Zelensky said his troops had taken back at least  towns, including Irpin and the Hostomel air base on the outskirts of the capital.It also regained control of the heavily contaminated Chernobyl nuclear site. He said that while Ukrainian forces had regained  towns in the Kyiv region, the battle raging in Ukraine’s eastern Donbas region and Kharkiv remained “extremely dficult”. Zelensky said: “The occupiers are withdrawing forces in the north of our country. The withdrawal is slow but noticeable. “Somewhere they are expelled with battles. Somewhere they leave positions on their own.” The MoD said Russian forces were withdrawing from the area around Kyiv, as Ukrainian forces advanced. The MoD’s intelligence assessment said: “Ukrainian forces continue to advance against withdrawing Russian forces in the vicinity of Kyiv.  “Along the north western axis, Ukrainian forces’ attempts to advance from Irpin towards Bucha and Hostomel are ongoing. “Russian forces are reported to have withdrawn from Hostomel airport, which has been subject to fighting since the first day of the conflict. “Along the eastern axis, Ukraine has re-taken several villages.” Zelensky said more than , people had escaped the besieged Mariupol – which has faced weeks of ferocious Russian shelling – through a humanitarian corridor in a convoy of buses and cars. At least , have been killed in the city and the estimated , who remain face shortages of food, water and electricity. Defence sources last night said that Nato is planning to send tanks to Ukraine.  Polish T-s could start arriving in days. Zelenskyy has been calling on Nato to send tanks and aircraft to help force the Russians out of his country. Putin’s negotiators this week said that Russian forces would ease back from attacks on Kyiv and northern Ukraine although shelling has continued and there is a fear that they are simply regrouping. Colonel Richard Kemp, a former British Infantry commander, said: “It’s not clear whether the Russians were ever intending to fight through Kiev street by street. “It is more likely Putin hoped Zelensky would capitulate as soon as Russia invaded and Kiev was threatened. “Encircling Kiev may also have been intended to fix Ukrainian forces in the city, preventing reinforcements being sent south and east to defend against Russian offensive action there. “It looks like they now wish to withdraw forces from the Kiev area to complete operations in Donbas. “That does not mean they won’t continue to attack Kiev and the surrounding area with artillery and air.” The UK has insisted it will not put troops on the ground in Ukraine but, along with NATO allies, it will supply defensive support to President Zelensky’s troops. The UK provided , anti-tank weapons. story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.When you purchased your subscription an email was sent to your account with your login details. title: ruby house
story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.When you purchased your subscription an email was sent to your account with your login details.
